6 Question 2

Below the required code is rewritten using dplyr and the pipe operator

flight1 <- flights |> 
  filter(month == 1)

carrier_vec <- flight1 |> 
  distinct(carrier)


carrier_dist_vec_mean <- flight1 |> 
  group_by(carrier) |> 
  summarise(mean_distance = mean(distance, na.rm = TRUE)) 


carrier_dist_vec_sd <- flight1 |> 
  group_by(carrier) |> 
  summarise(sd_distance = sd(distance, na.rm = TRUE))


dist_tbl <- inner_join(carrier_dist_vec_mean, carrier_dist_vec_sd)

dist_tbl |> arrange(mean_distance)
# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier mean_distance sd_distance
   <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
 1 YV               229          0  
 2 9E               476.       334. 
 3 EV               522.       294. 
 4 US               536.       553. 
 5 MQ               566.       223. 
 6 FL               691.       142. 
 7 OO               733         NA  
 8 WN               942.       496. 
 9 B6              1062.       681. 
10 DL              1220.       644. 
11 AA              1350.       626. 
12 UA              1462.       778. 
13 F9              1620          0  
14 AS              2402          0  
15 VX              2495.        98.2
16 HA              4983          0

7 Question 3

The code below counts the number of flights undertaken by the “OO” in month 1; only one flight was undertaken. Since the sample standard deviation is undefined for a sample size of 1 (due to division by 0), the standard deviation is listed as NA.

flight1 |> 
  filter(,carrier == "OO") |> 
  summarise(count = n())
# A tibble: 1 × 1
  count
  <int>
1     1

The following code demonstrates that for carriers with distance standard deviation of 0 have only one distinct distance. This means that the carrier covers the same distance for every flight and hence their mean distance is equal to the distance traveled every flight. There are thus no deviations from the mean and hence no standard deviation.

dist_tbl |> 
  filter(sd_distance == 0) |> 
  inner_join(flight1) |> 
  group_by(carrier) |> 
  summarise(distinct_vals = n_distinct(distance, na.rm = TRUE))
# A tibble: 4 × 2
  carrier distinct_vals
  <chr>           <int>
1 AS                  1
2 F9                  1
3 HA                  1
4 YV                  1

8 Question 4

flights |> 
  group_by(carrier, month) |> 
  summarise(avg = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
    pivot_wider(id_cols = "month", 
                names_from = carrier,
                values_from = avg)
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'carrier'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

9 Question 5

delayed_timely <- flights |> 
  filter(dep_delay > 0, arr_delay <= 0) |> 
  summarise(delayed_timely = n()) 

total <- flights |> 
  summarise(total = n())

tibble(delayed_timely, total, proportion = delayed_timely/total)
# A tibble: 1 × 3
  delayed_timely  total proportion
           <int>  <int>      <dbl>
1          35442 336776      0.105

10 Question 6

Below are the routes that more than one airline flies

#Routes that more than one airline flies

mult_routes <- flights |> 
  mutate(route = paste(origin, dest)) |> 
  group_by(route) |> 
  summarise(count = n_distinct(carrier)) |> 
  filter(count > 1)

mult_routes
# A tibble: 128 × 2
   route   count
   <chr>   <int>
 1 EWR ATL     4
 2 EWR AUS     2
 3 EWR BDL     2
 4 EWR BNA     2
 5 EWR BOS     3
 6 EWR BWI     2
 7 EWR CHS     2
 8 EWR CLE     2
 9 EWR CLT     3
10 EWR CVG     2
# ℹ 118 more rows

Below are the delays for each airline on each such route

delay.route.airline <-  flights |> 
  mutate(route = paste(origin, dest)) |> 
  inner_join(mult_routes) |> 
  select(carrier, route, arr_delay) |> 
  left_join(airlines) |> 
  group_by(route, name) |> 
  summarise(Average_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) 

delay.route.airline
# A tibble: 343 × 3
# Groups:   route [128]
   route   name                     Average_delay
   <chr>   <chr>                            <dbl>
 1 EWR ATL Delta Air Lines Inc.             10.0 
 2 EWR ATL Endeavor Air Inc.                -6.25
 3 EWR ATL ExpressJet Airlines Inc.         19.5 
 4 EWR ATL United Air Lines Inc.            10.5 
 5 EWR AUS Southwest Airlines Co.          -11.2 
 6 EWR AUS United Air Lines Inc.             4.28
 7 EWR BDL ExpressJet Airlines Inc.          6.78
 8 EWR BDL United Air Lines Inc.            22.6 
 9 EWR BNA ExpressJet Airlines Inc.         17.7 
10 EWR BNA Southwest Airlines Co.           -2.13
# ℹ 333 more rows

Below are calculations of the best and worst airlines in terms of average arrival delay for the aforementioned routes.

best <- delay.route.airline |> 
  group_by(route) |> 
  summarise(Average_delay = min(Average_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
  left_join(delay.route.airline) |> 
  rename(Best = Average_delay)

worst <- delay.route.airline |> 
  group_by(route) |> 
  summarise(Average_delay = max(Average_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
  left_join(delay.route.airline) |> 
  rename(Worst = Average_delay)


tbl <- best |> 
  inner_join(worst, by = "route")
tbl
# A tibble: 128 × 5
   route      Best name.x                   Worst name.y                  
   <chr>     <dbl> <chr>                    <dbl> <chr>                   
 1 EWR ATL  -6.25  Endeavor Air Inc.        19.5  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 2 EWR AUS -11.2   Southwest Airlines Co.    4.28 United Air Lines Inc.   
 3 EWR BDL   6.78  ExpressJet Airlines Inc. 22.6  United Air Lines Inc.   
 4 EWR BNA  -2.13  Southwest Airlines Co.   17.7  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 5 EWR BOS  -4.01  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.  6.87 JetBlue Airways         
 6 EWR BWI   5.95  Southwest Airlines Co.   20.1  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 7 EWR CHS -14     United Air Lines Inc.    16.2  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 8 EWR CLE  -3.71  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.  5.97 United Air Lines Inc.   
 9 EWR CLT   0.920 US Airways Inc.          20.5  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
10 EWR CVG   1.40  Endeavor Air Inc.        21.2  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
# ℹ 118 more rows

Clearly the airline with the worst delay is ExpressJet Airlines Inc. and the best is Endeavor Air Inc.

tbl |> 
  mutate(diff = Worst - Best) |> 
  arrange(-diff) |> 
  select(route, diff)
# A tibble: 128 × 2
   route    diff
   <chr>   <dbl>
 1 JFK ATL 127. 
 2 LGA XNA 112. 
 3 LGA ORD 108. 
 4 LGA MSY 102. 
 5 EWR STL  96.4
 6 LGA MSP  95.7
 7 EWR DTW  67.5
 8 LGA ATL  56.7
 9 LGA PBI  53.3
10 LGA IND  47.2
# ℹ 118 more rows

Clearly the route with greatest difference between the best and worst performing airline is JFK ATL.

flights |> 
  inner_join(airlines) |> 
  mutate(route = paste(origin, dest)) |> 
  filter(route == "JFK ATL") |> 
  group_by(name) |> 
  summarise(count = n())
# A tibble: 3 × 2
  name                     count
  <chr>                    <int>
1 Delta Air Lines Inc.      1874
2 Endeavor Air Inc.           55
3 ExpressJet Airlines Inc.     1

As is visible above, there are relatively few airlines which fly this route, furthermore ExpressJet Airlines (which had the worst delay) was only recorded flying this route once where as Endeavor Airlines (which had the best delay) was recorded flying this route 55 times. The route is clearly unfamiliar to ExpressJet and very familiar to Endeavor Airlines resulting in this great variance.

11 Question 7

Clearly there are 50 unique entries for “id” since 20 are displayed and the remainder are labelled as not being displayed.
